title: Monday, 19th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:03am

Morning then. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with stuff and etc.

BE11:03am

Too hot to think.

BE11:03am

I tried to beep through the office gate with my house keys this morning, so you probably shouldn't expect quality content over the next hour.

11:03 am
BE11:04am

Anyway, it's also Brexit Day. Happy Brexit Day! Have a picture.

BE11:04am

BE11:04am

David Davis, secretary of state for exiting the EU.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

He's on the right of Jim Davidson.

BE11:04am

If you want the crib notes, here's the FT's handy summary.

BE11:05am

https://www.ft.com...-8edb-58a4ede53f06

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Or if that's all too long and complicated you can have a browse of DD's Twitter, where he's already shown an impressive grasp of how the EU ... oh wait ..........

BE11:05am

https://twitter.com/DavidDavisMP/status/735770073822961664

BE11:05am

Ah.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

https://twitter.com/DavidDavisMP/status/735770127564607489

BE11:05am

Um.

BE11:05am

https://twitter.com/DavidDavisMP/status/740158994749259777

11:05 am
BE11:06am

Anyway. Good luck everyone.

undefined
BE11:06am

We're up-ish.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

FTSE ahead 36 points at 7500-ish, where it seems to have been stuck for about a fortnight.

BE11:09am

Most of the emails from spread betting market commentator types are waffling on about Asia overnight as an excuse for the rally, so that's good enough for us as well.

BE11:10am

In terms of news, wherever would be be without ..............

11:10 am
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 295.02, up 19.22 (+6.97%), High: 302.10, Low: 282.30, Volume: 1.70m
BE11:11am

I suspect, if you divvied up the last 12 years of Markets Live, at least 5% of the airtime has been spent on a midcap unprofitable grocery delivery firm.

BE11:11am

Today we have Amazon-Whole Foods, and whether it is good or bad news.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

The answer seems to be "Possibly both."

BE11:12am

As noted on the right, Exane upgrades.

BE11:12am

This is Andrew Gwynn. He and James Tracey at Redburn are the best of the Ocado analysts, I'd suggest.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

The big question is why buy supermarkets, wasn’t Amazon going to destroy them? We think the deal says that entry into food retail from the outside is just too difficult but the limitations of the store pick model mean its market share progress might still be subdued short-term. We’re minded to not overreact therefore but the deal is still bad news for the sector we think, unless of course you are a target. For us, Ocado might not be a target but the probability of a partnership just increased materially – we raise it to Outperform from Underperform, taking our TP to 325p (from 220p).

BE11:13am

Course, we simply don't know what Amazon's going to do with Whole Foods. Will it whittle down the c35% gross margin in order to grow the c1.5% US market share?

BE11:13am

Exane says, "maybe .............. but slowly."

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Because online grocery's really difficult.

BE11:13am

Remember that Ocado's gross margin isn't far off Whole Foods.

BE11:14am

And it operates in a tiny wee area of a tiny wee island that's the world's second-most developed for online groceries.(Korea's #1 I think.)

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Ocado has the strongest brand in the space and a trading history nearing two decades. And it still can't make a turn.

BE11:14am

It's fair to say that the grocery thing is a lot more complicated than just plugging the Whole Foods into the Amazon network. And it's not irrelevant that Amazon's gone for the "actual shops" route.

BE11:15am

All of which makes Whole Foods a launchpad, not an ............ um, space station. Back to Exane.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

We have to assume that Amazon is plugging Whole Foods into its existing mostly online ecosystem. We’d assume that Amazon is going to be store picking for the short-term but the store pick model isn’t that scalable (c15% of store sales seems to be the cap) and so Amazon’s advance might still be subdued. However, Whole Foods is not a landing but rather a launch pad for market share gains and though it might take time, a major step-up in the UK seems the next logical move.

BE11:15am

We doubt Amazon is going to collapse Whole Foods’ high gross margin to such an extent that it would impact industry gross margin (or in time, UK). Following the shopper may be more costly however. We’re minded to hold onto the tangible (high FCF %) so we retain Ahold Delhaize as Outperform but sell the earnings recoveries that could now be more vulnerable, notably Tesco.

BE11:15am

.......... or to put it another way:

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Whole Foods is arguably not the platform to launch pricing Armageddon from; had Amazon wanted to do that, there are plenty of other grocers it could have bought, potentially for a materially lower price. It is not to say that defending against Amazon is without cost however. If Amazon is launching a larger food retail platform that is more fully integrated into its other existing offerings (notably Prime) then Whole Foods owned by Amazon could be a much more exciting concept for shoppers. The mainstream therefore might need to spend money following their shoppers, which for those without online platforms could press the need for a rapid catch-up. For this reason, even though we still have questions on whether the deal could work for a partner, desperate times call for desperate measures and we think the probability of Ocado signing a partnership deal has increased materially.

BE11:16am

Merrill also talking Morrison and Ocado as the most likely in a wave of defensive-driven European consolidation, though I seem to have mislaid the note.

BE11:17am

(It was called "Keep calm and carry on(line)" so the loss might not have been entirely accidental.)

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Morgan Stanley, meanwhile, hedges its bets.

BE11:17am

History has shown that the market can sometimes over react when a leading company makes a new market entry. Additionally, Amazon's acquisition of a 450+ store chain validates that, unlike in non-food, in food retail it is a difficult task to operate a pure play online business profitably without bricks & mortar presence and/or a sizeable fresh supply chain. That being said, last week's news shows Amazon's commitment to make further inroads in grocery and given Amazon's scale and technological prowess, this is not a positive development for European grocers. It will likely translate into the listed grocers being further 'sandwiched' between privately-owned discounters and online operators. Given the low growth of the industry, likely lack of capacity rationalization in Europe's main national markets in the foreseeable future, as well as lack of consolidation (at a pan European or national level), this will likely lead to flat earnings growth in the medium term. As a result, we think the group has to be valued on a FCF yield basis. Among the conventional operators (i.e. excluding Jeronimo Martins or Colruyt), Ahold is the only listed name in Europe offering an attractive FCF yield (~9%). We find the rest of the group unattractive, particularly big box operators. As for Ocado, implications are mixed: negative for Ocado's core UK operations due to likely higher competition in UK online grocery, but positive for the strategic value of Ocado's online grocery fulfillment solution, the OSP.

BE11:18am

Otherwise .........

11:18 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 171.85, up 0.75 (+0.44%), High: 174.20, Low: 170.80, Volume: 11.68m
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 243.41, up 0.81 (+0.33%), High: 245.50, Low: 240.00, Volume: 2.09m
undefined
11:19 am
BE11:19am

On Imagination Tech, mentioned several times on the right ....

Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 122.50, down 4.75 (-3.73%), High: 125.75, Low: 121.00, Volume: 831.82k
BE11:19am

......... I haven't heard a specific story.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

And to that I'd add two very general observations.

BE11:20am

Volume was very lumpy in a lot of stocks last week, with closing auctions in particular unusually busy.

BE11:21am

Also, the whole iPhone supplier group has had a bit of a run-up.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Supply chain checks in Asia seem to have been positive in recent weeks, pre the iPhone8 launch. Apple watchers have been revising their numbers higher, to around 240m+ iPhones this year.

BE11:24am

And while Imagination's long term future under Apple remains in question, it's not impossible to believe that it continued to trade upwards with Dialog, AMS, STMicro and all those.

BE11:24am

If anyone knows a more interesting story re Imagination, feel free to give me a shout.

11:24 am
undefined
BE11:25am

Heading back into the risers, there's Capita.

BE11:26am

Which is, like Ocado, a consensus short so tends to be a bit lively.

11:26 am
Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 668.83, up 23.33 (+3.61%), High: 678.72, Low: 655.63, Volume: 1.57m
BE11:27am

Jefferies is going all-in the "under new management" turnaround theory.

BE11:27am

There is evidence of change under the Chairman, a full price for the CAS disposal would derisk the balance sheet, IFRS15 is benign, and equity markets seem willing to back management turnarounds at a very early stage. With the UK in perpetual political turmoil, trading will remain difficult but lowly valuation multiples underappreciate self-help. Capita is deeply unloved but risk/reward is slowly improving. We upgrade to Buy.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

This is post the last Capita trading statement being mildly positive, in spite of all the negatives.

BE11:28am

(@wolfelix: not sure I follow that argument.)

BE11:28am

Chairman driving change; New CEO can do more. It’s difficult to assess a management turnaround story without a CEO but our channel checks indicate the Chairman has driven considerable change since last September. Further portfolio reviews could result in non-core sales but our initial calculations suggest a modest EPS impact. Recent events at Serco and MITIE suggest that a new CEO could remove significant cost if organisational complexity is reduced - Capita has a reputation for running operating units on a stand-alone basis so there may be considerable duplication.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

The forecast is also that the CAS sale will get done at a decent price, perhaps £775m, which would be enough to cut ND/EBITDA to 2.1x.

BE11:31am

Reuters had a report overnight naming Link Group bidder.

BE11:03am

Hot, innit.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

https://www.reuter...-m-a-idUSKBN1962KL

BE11:32am

Anyway, back to Jefferies.

BE11:32am

Balance sheet remains a key risk. The 30 June covenant test feels uncomfortably tight as our initial calculations suggest 2.9x ND/EBITDA versus a 3.0x covenant. If the CAS disposal is well advanced then we think a breach would result in compensation to note holders rather than an equity issue but we are mindful that delayed interims provide the flexibility for Capita to discuss options with shareholders.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

We upgrade FY17E EPS by 4% after assessing H1/H2 swing factors. Capita anticipates “profitable growth” in FY18E but we are more conservative and assume flat EBITA.

BE11:33am

Depressed valuation multiples (the 5% dividend yield and 7% FCF yield are particularly notable) should offer considerable upside if EPS/FCF stabilise. We raise our PT from 465p to 750p which is based on 14x FY18E PE and 10.5x EV/EBITDA (the bottom of the 10-year range). Risks include political uncertainty, balance sheet leverage, delayed bid timetables and mobilisation.

undefined
11:33 am
BE11:33am

One postscript on Imagination, which I hadn't noticed until a reader pointed it out.

BE11:34am

http://www.investe...1706161320273564I/

BE11:34am

Tsinghua Unigroup going sub 3%.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Tsinghua owns Spreadtrum, which uses Imagination licences. When it went over 3% back in May the shares popped 11% on the idea that it was a potential white knight.

undefined
BE11:37am

Ug. Too hot. .... Philips mentioned on the right.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Times reporting that Dan Loeb’s Third Point has been stake building.

BE11:38am

https://www.thetim...-adea-f9bd8bb04f4c

BE11:38am

Good story for a freelancer to land. I can see that kid having a future ..........

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Anyway, here's JP Morgan to talk us through the Philips breakup angle.

BE11:40am

Our OW investment base is centered on two key drivers. First, we
believe that Philips has a margin improvement potential in large Imaging (mid single digit in 2016 vs Siemens greater than 20%) and in Connected Care (break-through R&D burden results by 300bp). We also believe that there is still a sizable overhead cost reduction opportunity. In addition, we believe it can re-rate given that it trades at the low end of where HealthTech, Consumer or Capital Goods peers trade. The re-rating is linked to the margin improvement as the negative perception of investors on the Philips assets is more a reflection on how they were run historically than a view on the assets itself, in our view. Philips management has been working hard over the past years to lift the potential while also investing into the future. It is nearing the completion of the exit from Lighting and has addressed a large chunk of the legacy liabilities (pensions, continent liabilities, buyback of expensive debt). The company has generally delivered on consensus earnings expectations. When there were setbacks, these mostly related to history catching up with Philips, like with a number of FDA issues dating back to 2014 and before which are rooted in issues around execution, management and diligence. Our frustration at times has been that Philips management has not been clear enough on future capital allocation, for example providing a framework for M&A vs buybacks and providing financial acquisition criteria. As an absolute minimum, we believe the company should avoid dilution from the script dividend and compensation programs. As a “value” story with a strong balance sheet, it should buy back shares to maximize the longer-term upside for current investors, not issue shares, in our view. We see an opportunity to deploy the excess cash on the balance sheet. We estimate a €2bn net cash position by the end of this year pro-forma for the exit of the remaining stake in LIGHT and the completion of the Lumileds deal. This compares to EBITDA of €2.8bn (2017 JPME). Hence at for example at 1x net debt/EBITDA, this indicates close to €5bn excess capital or more than €5 per share. We are not opposed to Philips making acquisitions and the only major acquisition made under new management (Volcano) has been a success. Our concern more relates to the currently generally very high valuations of targets and the issue that Philips still has to re-rate towards its peer groups to reduce the multiple gap between itself and potential targets. Therefore there should be an extra level of scrutiny when it comes to deciding whether to invest in its own stock (share buyback) or make acquisitions. On portfolio, we generally don’t have a problem with the combination of Consumer and Healthcare assets given some synergies around the brand and the company’s strong position in home healthcare. Whether the Domestic Appliances business fits is a different question but given its good performance, we do not see any urgency to exit, which could be earnings dilutive.

undefined
11:42 am
BE11:43am

Someone was talking Boohoo/Asos earlier.

Boohoo.Com PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 251.75, up 9.5 (+3.92%), High: 253.50, Low: 246.50, Volume: 6.29m
ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 6,118, up 52 (+0.86%), High: 6,295, Low: 6,086, Volume: 58.48k
11:44 am
BE11:44am

I guess there's an Amazon readthrough, though it feels tangential, and a Wal-Mart-Bonobos readthrough, though that's small beer.

BE11:45am

What there is, for Boohoo at least, is a push from Stifel.

BE11:45am

They've done a survey.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

BE11:47am

There's lots more of that.

BE11:47am

11:48 am
BE11:48am

And ...........

BE11:48am

BE11:49am

Sometimes, just sometimes, it's worth making the graph logarithmic.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Anyway, here's the upshot.

BE11:49am

Our Proprietary Social Media Analytics analysis reveals the that level of social media engagement (measured in terms of customers’ interaction with the brand) gives a fair sense of a company’s performance ahead of the reporting period. We believe our Proprietary Social Media Analytics will be pivotal to forecasting the company’s future sales performance. In our methodology, we believe we have identified which social media channel is the best predictor of current sales: we determine what drives customer engagement the most (among photos, videos and links), and we focus our analysis on the channel that best captures customers’ activity. In this report, we provide an introduction to our Analytics methodology that we use to support our analysis and forecast sales.

BE11:50am

Coo!

11:50 am
BE11:50am

ASOS is the leading UK fast fashion online company targeting 20-somethings around the world. Leveraging world-class customer service and the latest technologies, ASOS positions itself at the forefront of the fast-growing fashion business. The company bases its operations in three main geographies, the UK, USA and EU (especially France and Germany). The company's operations rely on four distribution centres: Barnsley in the UK, Eurohubs 1&2 in the EU, and one warehouse in Ohio, USA. By leveraging the mobile channel, which represents 70% of traffic and 58% of total orders, as well as its new modular IT platform, ASOS delivers a frictionless customer experience, even at peak times (e.g. Black Friday). When looking at ASOS, it helps to compare the company to the other three main quoted competitors in the online fashion arena: Amazon, Zalando and boohoo. Ranked by degree of fashion authority and third-party brands offering, we see ASOS as the best positioned.

BE11:51am

Capital expenditure doubling next year, could have a negative impact on trade. We believe the increase of the FY17 capex/sales ratio to 9% (FY17E capex +111% Y/Y, from £79m to £167m) may have a negative impact on trade, as it did in 2011 and 2014, when high capital investments led to a sales growth decline and share price underperformance.
Valuation. Our 6,250p target price is derived from a discounted cash flow valuation. We define three potential case scenarios (upside FV of 7,100p, central TP of 6,250p, downside FV of 4,800p), which are driven by peer comparisons and different forecast assumptions. Our upside case scenario features a peer comparison within the “Best in class” companies. We identify stocks with similar fundamental characteristics (high growth, international, online, clothing) and we monitor the relative performance. We think this is particularly helpful in order to determine fair value on a relative basis.

BE11:52am

(@wayneJ: no nylon.)

11:52 am
BE11:52am

And here they come on Boohoo.

BE11:53am

We upgrade our rating from Hold to Buy as we do not believe the current share price fully reflects expected FY18 sales and earnings. Our estimates are at the top end of the consensus range (Stifel FY18E Sales +8% and PBT +11%) and are supported by our Proprietary Social Media Analytics analysis, which shows a higher level of customer engagement compared to close competitors. Furthermore, we believe in worldwide fulfilment from the UK, underpinned by the warehousing expansion (recently announced) and the UK-based supply chain. Our 288p TP implying 19% upside potential, is DCF based and reflects a £3bn sales opportunity.

BE11:54am

With the two new warehouses, the group will have warehousing capacity up to an ambitious £3bn net sales capacity, by FY20. We do not foresee capacity constraints in the meantime, as PLT will be placed in a third-party facility. We find the decision to expand warehouse capacity in the UK and fulfil worldwide from the UK to be in line with boohoo’s supply chain strategy, which leverages close suppliers relationships.
Multibrands strategy. As PLT exponential growth demonstrated and management recently confirmed, the two recently acquired businesses should drive domestic and international sales growth “leveraging that capability that we have got at boohoo”. PLT benefited from both boohoo’s legacy operational infrastructure and expertise and we believe that the multibrand strategy should support the two businesses even further.
Valuation. While we recognise the increased execution risk, we believe the company is moving in the right direction. We upgrade our DCF-based TP from 192p to 288p (19% upside potential). BUY.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Hm.

BE11:56am

It's an amazing success story, Boohoo. But it's not entirely proven whether it has the management and corporate structures in place to be a £3bn turnover company.

BE11:57am

Exhibit A: the PrettyLittleThing acquisition. But let's save that for another time.

11:57 am
undefined
BE11:58am

Nearly done, thankfully.

BE11:58am

Haven't mentioned the exclusive-to-all on Sainsbury.

11:58 am
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 258.00, up 5.7 (+2.26%), High: 258.30, Low: 253.00, Volume: 3.89m
BE11:59am

Preferred bidder for Nisa, £130m

BE12:00pm

Somewhere on my phone I have photos of the Nisa on Perth Road, Dundee. Just in case you want a clearer view of what Sainsbury is buying.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

(Maybe buying.)

BE12:01pm

While I look for them, here's Bernstein.

BE12:01pm

We weren't looking for SBRY to do another deal. We want them to delever. But when the bankers knock on the door, the board has to consider it. The wholesale sector is clearly very worried about the Tesco/Booker deal, making the price probably attractive. If SBRY doesn’t buy it, somebody else may and gain scale over SBRY.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Tie-up would have similar benefits for Nisa as for Booker's deal with Tesco: (1) Nisa will get material COGS reduction when their £1.4bn of sales are combined with Sainsbury's £23bn. (2) Nisa will get access to Sainsbury's private label and fresh food supply chain, giving a big improvement to the products they sell to their symbol stores. (3) In the long run Nisa symbols may get access to Sainsbury's online distribution network.

BE12:03pm

For Sainsbury's deal provides low cost convenience growth and click and collect points: (1) The convenience channel remains one of the fastest growing parts of the UK food retail market. Growth by the symbol model would be low capital growth in this market for Sainsbury's (2) The deal could provide upwards of 2,000 new click and collect points for Sainsbury's. Synergies could be ~£50m. Based on the Tesco Booker guided synergies of £200m, we expect synergies for Sainsbury's-Nisa to be £50m.

BE12:03pm

£130m purchase price implies EV £200m and EV/EBITDA of ~27x ex synergies and 3.5x including synergies. However Nisa is currently mutual, owned by the symbol group operators. A sale to SBRY may change the profit motive of the business and increase EBITDA further.

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

Found them! Google Photos is very good, isn't it?

BE12:04pm

Anyway, this is Nisa's superstore in the wealthiest bit of Dundee, where all the university types live, a couple of days before last Christmas.

BE12:04pm

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Not just the booze cabinet either.

BE12:05pm

BE12:06pm

The guy behind the counter said they hadn't had a proper delivery in months, but also that the owners insisted it wasn't closing down.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Good luck, Sainsbury.

undefined
BE12:06pm

Look at the time! We're done.

12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

Thanks for joining. Ta for getting us through.

BE12:07pm

Murph might! (won't) be back tomorrow!

BE12:08pm

Last heard he's stuck in Maputo.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

Where it's probably cooler than London.

BE12:08pm

Join us tomorrow to see if he makes it back in time! (He won't.)

BE12:08pm

Until then, afternoon all.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

£800m.
